reviewText:
Now you've been following Gamindustri for quite awhile, but have you ever heard of Gamarket? If you're a long-time fan of the Neptunia franchise, then you're aware that there are many dimensions. In Gamarket, Noire rules. Thanks to the help of her 18 generals, she has defeated the other CPUs, and is well on her way to achieving total domination...well... was anyway. It seems that she has had a temporary setback, and it's up to you, the player, to get her back on her feet. With your help, Noire just might be able to unite Gamarket. Hey, you might even get the opportunity to win over the Goddess of Lonely Hearts. I wish I was joking about that last part.

When designing a spin-off, it's important to consider the intended audience. While it makes sense that fans of the Neptunia RPGs can also enjoy other genres, there has to the right balance of depth and fun-factor, or else the developer risks pushing those fans away. In this regard, Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart is a success. It delivers a thoroughly competent S-RPG, without drowning players in stats and a multitude of convoluted sub-systems. The nendoroid" art-direction suits the game-play portions really well. The visuals help set the game apart from other entries in the franchise.

reviewText:
Much like Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed, this is another spin-off of the Hyperdimension Neptunia series. This time, they went full on SRPG, grid and all.

If you've played the main entries in the series (if not, I'll sum it up at the bottom), a lot of the staples are here. There's item plans to craft, discs to burn, and a bunch of processor equipment you won't ever bother using. Oh, there's also still a ton of anime boobs, so if that's your thing, no need to worry about that being left out.

Gameplay is pretty similar to other SRPGs you might have played, such as Final Fantasy Tactics or Disgaea. As mentioned before, the playing field is on a grid. Turns are divided into a player phase and an enemy phase, instead of rotating through all active combatants based on speed. You can activate HDD mode on the characters to give them boosts. This can only be used once per character per fight, lasts 3 turns, and makes a huge difference if used correctly. Some characters, like Noire, get extra bonuses in this form as well. She can act twice per turn in HDD form, for instance.

The world map is very similar to the main games, where you just pick different icons on a map (or a list, if you want) for things like the shop, making plans, and the like. There's an option for the missions as well, so don't think you're going to wander around a map and get in fights like in Final Fantasy Tactics. It's much similar to Disgaea in this regard. There are story missions as well as side missions, and you can replay the story missions in a simulation mode. This allows you to use any characters you'd like for the missions instead of who was required in the story, and gives you different rewards for completion of the mission as well.

Experience is awarded per action instead of per kill, similar to most SRPGs. You will usually get a tiny bit more for a kill, but any valid action other than moving will earn you something. This makes it worth your while to spam super weak healing items each turn if you don't have a real action you want to take.

The story cutscenes are the same as the main series. You'll see a lot of the same backgrounds and characters you did in those games, as well as a lot of the same enemies because everyone knows they love recycling assets at Idea Factory. I'm just saying what we're all thinking.

The lily system is here as well, but it is a bit different. Standing next to one or more characters when you use a skill will cause the nearby characters to (ugh) kiss you on the cheek, lowering the SP cost of the skill and raising your LP (Lily Points?) and possibly your lily rank. LP is reset after each battle, is one total for the whole party, and ranges from 0 to 100, raising by 20 per kiss. If you get kissed by more than one character at a time, each kiss will give less than the full 20 points, however. Still, it's not a big downside; getting kissed twice at the same time gives 30, which is fine. You can spend all 100 for a strong attack, and you need 30 to activate HDD mode.

The challenge system from Hyperdimension Neptunia 3 is back. If you're not familiar with this, it's a list of various things that when completed give some bonus to the character. Each challenge has various ranks, with the required number of the action and the bonus increasing as the rank goes up. For instance, moving a total of 25 spaces as a character will complete rank 1 of their movement challenge and award them +2 agility, if I'm not remembering incorrectly. It might not sound like much, but a lot of these are basically free stats, as you will complete a lot of these without even trying. The stat increases for the higher ranks get better as well, and they stack. Sadly, the required number of actions for the higher ranks will climb to ridiculous levels right along side the stats. You probably *will* have to try to complete the higher ranks of most challenges.

There's a new system where you earn sim points as you buy things from the shop. These points can be spent in a Noire sim mode, which is basically buying her things for her bedroom and upgrading the actual room itself. You also get requests from citizens in this mode, which function a lot like the quests in the main series, except without the actual quest. You just pick a choice from a menu to solve their request, and bingo. It's done. Picking the correct" response can lead to getting some extra stuff

reviewText:
I had a small amount of trouble setting this game up at first. While the game itself is rather good, the shoddy porting and over-pricedness is quite off-putting.

Negatives:

Unlike IF's previous PSVita port (Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed) there are no issues with fuzzy screen resolution, the only fixes for which were to either utilize NVIDIA DSR, or to use some software called GeDoSaTo to render the game in 4k and then downscale it to 1080p (Both of these methods would break the Steam overlay in different ways as sacrifice for having real 1080p). However with this not being an issue in Hyperdevotion Noire, there are even more problems than last time. When the game is set to fullscreen, minimising it causes it to crash. The framerate is locked at 30fps regardless of your video settings (The refresh rates are even listed next to the chosen screen resolution, making it even more irritating). This gets very annoying as all the previous HDN PC games had smooth-as-silk lovely 60fps. What's more, it made me realise how choppy 30fps actually is. Hopefully someone will eventually write a patch in the form of an executable file where you can just open it once, click 'patch' and then you're done with it, forever. While you can remap the controls on your keyboard (but let's be honest, HDN games aren't supposed to be played on a keyboard), you cannot remap the controls on your gamepad. I see no acceptable reason for this, whether it is a bug or is intentional. There are always going to be people who have custom button maps for different games, so if your game allows for the use of a gamepad then the ability to remap it should be there, no question. The BGM does not loop properly, it reaches the loop point, goes slightly beyond that and then jumps back to the beginning. While this may not annoy most people, it most definitely annoys an Audiophile like myself. This next gripe isn't a bug, but is definitely the product of some lazy programming. The monster drop loot isn't 100% random. What I mean by this is that for example, if I were in a mission full of multiples of the same monster that has the potential to drop a plethera of different items, each one of those monsters is locked to a specific selection of the drops it is supposed to yield. Basically, if there is a specific item you are after from that monster, you have to attack a specific one of those monsters, even though they are all the same monster. I would also have liked to see a feature where you can speed through the enemy's turn, because it does feel a bit sluggish at times.

Positives:

I rejoiced when I noticed that IF had finally come out of the Dark Ages of PC gaming, and there was an option for anti-aliasing in the video settings. The actual gameplay itself is quite enjoyable, and I feel that this style of Strategy RPG fits the Neptunia genre quite nicely. The gratuitous 4th wall breaking dialogue never ceases to amuse me. While I am aware that other people think that the missions are boring, it is called a strategy game for a reason. You do have to plan stuff out and use your head to be good at it, so if that doesn't tickle your fancy then you shouldn't have bought the game in the first place in full knowledge of the fact that it's a strategy based RPG, only to complain about it. Some people are put off by the fact that Noire meets a guy that she fancies and has a minor love rivalry with Saori. To be honest, I don't understand these complaints either. It's an HDN game with Noire as the main character this time, and with her lonely nature, it actually seems quite fitting to have this little addition in the story. Nor do I understand why people hate the lily boost system. It's in the game because it fits the style of combat layed out for the dungeons. Deal with it. If you're really one of those people who enjoys fanservice, you definitely shouldn't be complaining.

Verdict:

Good story, good gameplay, shoddy porting, laced with pesky bugs. Buy it if you're a tolerant and patient person, and you like Hyperdimension Neptunia. If you don't fulfill both of those criteria, save your money so that you in turn don't clog up the forums. Two birds with one stone.

7.5/10 or A- or however you grade games these days I dunno any more...

reviewText:
Indroduction
Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart takes the series familiar CPUs in a new direction once again, this time taking the series into the turn-based, tactical role-playing strategy realm.

Gameplay
Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart sets itself apart from the previous Hyperdimention Neptunia games available on Steam in several ways. The number one way is the game is now more about tactics and strategy than it previously had been. Using the terrain to your advantage is one of the strategy elements. Each weapon type in the game has its own hit box. For example, spears can hit two squares away but can’t hit a higher or lower elevation. On the other hand, swords are limited to one square away but can hit one level above or below.  A hit from the side or the back will do more damage than hitting a character from the front and also reduces their chance to counter attack. You need to plan your moves out carefully as all characters have a limited amount of mobility. For instance, you cannot walk through an enemy or go over a wall with a higher level than your jump score will allow you to scale. This means you can easily get yourself trapped in a corner if you don’t plan your route carefully. In addition to having to figure out where you want to end up once you make your single move for that turn, you need to pay attention to the route your character plans to take to get there. Your characters are a bit like Lemmings that will blindly fling themselves over ledges or walk into traps if you tell them to. Changing the direction your character is facing allows you to adjust their route to help avoid those situations. Just because you dodged a trap doesn’t mean it won’t get you though. If you stop next to a trap, an enemy will often use its knockback attack to try to push you into the trap setting it off.  As you can see, there is a lot of planning, strategy and tactics involved in this game but there is even more than that to consider.

Each character in the game has its own abilities. Using these abilities, regardless of the intended target, will cause any characters that are one square away from the user to boost that ability’s effect. This means that if you cluster five of your characters in a plus shape and have the one in the middle cast a buff or long range attack, the other four characters will “peck” the caster enhancing the effect and boosting their Lily Ranks in the process. The higher the Lily Rank, the more effective the boost will be. You may be thinking that a good strategy would be to cluster your units and let the enemy come to you. There is a drawback to that plan though; some abilities can hit multiple targets. Instead of hitting just one of your characters with their strong attack, it’s possible they could hit multiple or all of them. Now you can see the tactics in this game are quite complex and not to be taken lightly. There is one more thing to cover on the tactics side though.

Elements are introduced as a way to play a pseudo rock, paper, scissors game. One element is stronger against another element but in turn is weaker to yet another element. Some chests found in the levels can only be opened using an elementally infused normal attack (skills and abilities usually have no effect on objects). Having characters with each of the elements available will aid you in looting each of the levels effectively assuming the characters have the ability (jump score, etc.) to reach the chest before the rest of your crew either kills off the enemies, or the enemy you were saving alive dies to a counter attack.  There are still more tactical elements to this game, but I will leave those to you to discover.

Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart features a crafting system. As you kill various monsters and complete missions you will aquire drops. These drops allow you to fabricate various things you will need to survive. Better weapons and items can all be crafted. This is where the strategy comes into play. Each piece of equipment has different effects. Sometimes you must make a trade off. To increase your movement range, you may have to reduce your defense a smidge. For the most part, you only need to craft a new item once for it to then appear in the store. This means you don’t have to worry too much about tracking down something you don’t currently have enough of to make another of the same. Buying from the store has its advantages too. Whenever you make a purchase you get Sim Points. Consider them like customer loyalty points of sorts. You will use these points to upgrade Noire’s house. The various things you buy will be added to her home and you can talk to them to get tips or fun conversations. You can also craft and name your own games within the game. Games are an upgrade that allows you to pick and choose what perks you want based on the elements that went into making the game.

Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart isn’t set in Gameindustri like the Hyperdimention Neptunia series, it is set in Gamarket. The four CPU Goddesses are all vying for total control of Gamarket. The series, if you are completely unfamiliar with it, is a satire of the current game market. Each of the CPUs represents one of the major console brands. Noire of Laststation, who as the title suggests is the star of the game much to Neptune’s displeasure, tries to end the fighting by listening to a strangers suggestion. This leads all of the Shares (think of them as likes/upvotes/retweets) in the land to disappear leaving the CPUs powerless and Gamarket in a political power vacuum.  I won’t spoil the story by going further, but it is quite in-depth. Much like previous games in the series, the gameplay is bookended by long expositional scenes. These are often cute, humours and quite enjoyable. It can also be quite fun trying to figure out who the next General pays homage to. For example, one of them named Lid, is a Solid Snake reference. She likes hiding in cardboard boxes and using air ducts to move around.

The art style in this game might be a little off-putting to some at first, but eventually it grows on you even if you had doubts going in. The Anime style characters are now Chibi during game play and resume their usual Anime form when talking to each other between missions. Chibi means they have oversized heads and tiny bodies. The style actually suits the way the battlefield works, and I think that having normal characters would have likely looked a bit weird there. Being Chibi lets you see their face clearly so you know who it is you are controlling just by looking at them. If you are being off put by the Chibi art style and plan on skipping it for solely that reason, you are doing yourself a great disservice.

Overall, Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart is a great turn-based, tactical role-playing strategy game. It is reminiscent of Final Fantasy Tactics so if you enjoyed that take on the Final Fantasy series, you will more than likely enjoy this take on the Hyperdimention Neptunia series. Current fans will not be disappointed either!

reviewText:
First of all, I have to say that this is the first time I play a game of the Neptunia series. I always heard great many things about this franchise, not only because of the half naked females of course, but also for its rather interesting setting that tends to appeal to gamers and the huge amount of customization and turn-based combat that these games tend to provide and so, because of that, I decided I’d give this one a chance. So far, for someone who had never played a game of this series before, I must say that I’m really enjoying the universe so far and I plan to play the other games as well.

Story:

Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart takes place in the world of Gamarket, a place where games are released at an unrelenting pace, which is also divided into four different nations, each with its own rulling goddess, or CPU - Console Patron Unit. These nations are constantly at war with each other, seeking to expand their control and convert the faith of the citizens into power in the form of shares.

Thanks to the evil plot of a certain mysterious character, a chain of unfortunate events starts to unfold, which results in the breakdown of the Sharicite, the physical representation of the peoples shares and the CPUs power. This forces the four goddesses to unite themselves in order to save the world of Gamarket. While I assume that this will feel like a very generic storyline to some people, I like it and find it rather interesting and each of the characters is unique and has its own personality.

Gameplay:

I think I wouldn’t be mistaken if I said that the game is split 50/50 by two very different genres. It is a mixture of a visual novel with tactical/strategy RPG elements, such as party turn-based combat.

The visual novel part of the game is pretty much just dialogue, which is voice acted for the most part. You’ll spend a lot of time interacting with the main protagonist, Noire, the CPU who presides over Lastation, one of the regions of Gamarket. Visually I really like the art design, but I understand some people will find it abhorrent, but those people will most likely not even read this, so yeah. That said, some of the characters are pretty much half naked, and even though I have no problem with that, I’m sure some people won’t find it appealing. The conversations are also full of suggestive themes, puns and sexual jokes.

Once you unlock the Lastation city screen, you’ll be able to do tons of stuff here including, selling, buying and crafting items, you can also talk to various different characters, take on missions or go and talk to Noire on her room. On Noire’s room, there is also some sort of dating/visual novel aspect in the form of customizing her room and answering to requests of the citizens with her, which will eventually unlock some extra scenes. Still, if you don’t want any of that you can completely ignore it. If you go to your Mission HQ, you can play new missions and simulations. Simulations consist on replaying old missions to get more rewards. You can also choose if you want to go straight for the main story missions or take on some side missions which, despite not providing any sort of story, they still give you some nice rewards.

As for the RPG side of the game, it comes in different ways such as customizing your characters with many different weapons and pieces of equipment and loot that you get either by killing enemies or completing missions. The combat is presented in a chibi art style, which contrasts with the visual design of the rest of the game and I find it be rather lovely. Combat itself is turn-based, which means that in each turn your characters can move and attack once, and movement is grid based. Still, you can move before or after performing an offensive action. When choosing an enemy to attack, you’ll be able to see how much damage you’ll do and its accuracy, as well as the enemy’s counter rate and expected damage. By killing enemies you’ll get loot and experience points which will allow you to level up your characters. Combat also rewards you for placing units next to each other when using special abilities, by improving the relationship between the two characters and granting you points to use more powerful skills.

Initially you’ll only control one character, the main protagonist - Noire (Black Heart), but soon enough more will join your cause. Even though I enjoy a lot games with turn-based combat, I do think that this is one of the weakest points of the game, albeit still a good one. Combat can get somewhat repetitive, especially if you plan on playing every single mission and simulation more than once. Some of the levels in which you fight offer some variety such as traps like electrified fences and floor plates, or the addition of height/verticality.

Final Verdict:Tons of customization
Lovely visual design
Catchy soundtrack - even though I don’t understand the lyrics
Robust turn-based combat system
Storyline is a mixed bag - it might feel generic to some but I like it and find it rather interesting
Funny dialogue, albeit somewhat cringe at times
Framerate capped at 28Hyperdevotion Noire lets you experience a visually appealing, charming and funny story that takes place in a ”gamer friendly world”. It has a pretty solid combat system that offers some replay value with different combinations and because of that, I recommend this game to both fans of visual novels and SRPGs. Needless to say that it this is must check for fans of the Neptunia series.

reviewText:
A new world!

A new system!

A new main character!

A present from the first character poll where Lady Black Heart won (see V-Generation for jokes), we have this offering from IF, Compa, and Sting. Thus forcing the question of if buying this game really gives that many shares to Lady Black Heart at all? I mean Iffy and Compa are clearly citizens of Planeptune....

Now, I'm sure Proper worshippers of Lady Black Heart have already played this game through more than once on their Unis, but some people probably haven't. Let's take a look at what we got going on here.

Welcome to Gamarket, another dimension in the Vast expanses of the Neptunia Multiverse. Here, Noire is pretty much in charge and controls most of the shares. However, Noire is still Noire and a certain Eggplant looking person made her fall into a trap, that not even Neptune would fall for. All hell has broken loose and the Shares in the world are in shambles, after a little bit of bickering Lady Black Heart takes charge of the other CPUs and sets to regain the shares of the world from her former 12 generals.

Joining the lovely CPUs is Noire's new Secretary. It's apparently a male, but since Males don't get faces in Neptunia we don't actually see him and it seems much of the adventure takes place from his point of view, and he may or may not get closer to his boss as the game goes on.

Pros
+An unpresidented look at Lady Noire as a character, especially for Steam Audiences.
+ Grid based Tactical battles require a little bit of thought and do make you have to different types of objectives
+ 3 difficulty modes
+ Panstu everywhere!
+ Noire's Generals are all new and represent different game franchises like Metal Gear, Street Fighter, Dragon Quest, ect and are exclusive to this game
+ The girls kiss to power each other up! The Lilly system is in OVERDRIVE

Cons
-The port is horrendus with a lot of lag spikes for apparently no reason. Those will probably get fixed if I know Iffy though.
- The CPUs are obviously different then the ones we know, and can be out of character. For example, Noire looking for informality in her employees, or Neptune genuinely getting offended when someone calls her out on her laziness.
- The Secretary (you) have some lines like I'll lead the way... SO HARD!"
- Translation gripes that come with the territory
- Little sisters are a negative. In this day and age it's hard to imagine Noire without Uni by her side (Especially since this game is a Uni Port)
- Iffy and Compa are DLC

A very simplistic strategy based in the Nep universe, Very easy (too easy) not really meant for fans of the strategy genre but instead for fans of the Nep games.
This is a fan service game complete with a silent self insert character with the focus really being on Noire rather than the in-game world.

If you havent played a Nep game before or ended up here from searching the strategy tag i cant really recomend this as the cast and thier humour is the main selling point not the combat.

If you have played a nep game and enjoy the series i can recommend this as its a nice change of pace from the normal playstyle of the other games....but id wait to get it on sale which being a nep game will happen almost all the time!

reviewText: At first, I was not certain how to feel about the self-insertion of the player into the story of this game. But it turned out to be alright, it only acted as a medium for you to feel more emotion towards the characters. The story was very fun to play through, and the game itself operates fluidly and wonderfully. I enjoyed the challenges and mechanics different quests would give you to overcome. The minigames, like Noire Sim, were also pretty fun.\nIt isn't my favorite spin-off, but it's pretty decently made. I highly recommend it, and also suggest to buy the DLC to support Idea Factory to make more fantastic games like this.
